dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So a new Pfizer-funded report is claiming there's no significant link between Covid-19 and psychiatric illness—what do you make of that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So a new Pfizer-funded report is claiming there's no significant link between Covidminus nineteen and psychiatric illness-what do you make of that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In another worrying set of findings for the long-term impact of Covid-19, a new peer reviewed study has confirmed reported links between psychiatric illness and Covid-19, with nearly one in five Covid-19 patients developing a mental illness within three months of testing positive for the virus and those with pre-existing mental conditions being 65% more likely to be diagnosed with Covid-19, even accounting for other risk factors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's led by Dr. Anthony Fauci at the CDC, which is uh, pretty surprising given earlier narratives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's led by Dr. Anthony Fauci at the C D C, which is uh, pretty surprising given earlier narratives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Paul Harrison, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Oxford and leader of the study, said the findings validate worries that Covid-19 survivors will be at a greater risk of mental health problems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they looked at 32 million health records across Europe—that's a huge sample size.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they looked at thirty two million health records across Europe-that's a huge sample size.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By examining the health records of 69 million people in the U.S., including over 62,000 Covid-19 patients, researchers from the University of Oxford and NIHR Oxford Health Biomedical Research Centre found evidence that Covid-19 increases a persons risk of developing psychiatric illness, with one in five receiving a diagnosis within three months of testing positive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But only included fewer than 5,000 Covid patients though, which seems kinda small in comparison, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But only included fewer than five thousand Covid patients though, which seems kinda small in comparison, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By examining the health records of 69 million people in the U.S., including over 62,000 Covid-19 patients, researchers from the University of Oxford and NIHR Oxford Health Biomedical Research Centre found evidence that Covid-19 increases a persons risk of developing psychiatric illness, with one in five receiving a diagnosis within three months of testing positive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and they're saying only one in a hundred people got a psychiatric diagnosis within three months of testing positive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and they're saying only one in a hundred people got a psychiatric diagnosis within three months of testing positive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In another worrying set of findings for the long-term impact of Covid-19, a new peer reviewed study has confirmed reported links between psychiatric illness and Covid-19, with nearly one in five Covid-19 patients developing a mental illness within three months of testing positive for the virus and those with pre-existing mental conditions being 65% more likely to be diagnosed with Covid-19, even accounting for other risk factors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is way lower than what a lot of people were expecting, honestly. And they even found that depression rates weren't elevated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is way lower than what a lot of people were expecting, honestly. And they even found that depression rates weren't elevated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Not all mental illnesses were more likely to be seen in Covid-19 patients, the researchers said, with rates of anxiety, depression and insomnia most elevated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But they did notice higher rates of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders—that part stood out to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they did notice higher rates of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders-that part stood out to me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers said they found no clear signs of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders in Covid-19 patients, which includes schizophrenia, though they did note the higher likelihood of relapse in patients already living with the conditions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then they also said people with pre-existing mental illness were less likely to get Covid? That feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then they also said people with pre-existing mental illness were less likely to get Covid? That feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There was also an unexpected finding in the research, indicating that those with a pre-existing psychiatric illness are 65% more likely to be diagnosed with Covid-19, even when other factors are accounted for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Dr. Deborah Birx was on the team too—she said this expected finding needs more investigation before we draw conclusions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Dr. Deborah Birx was on the team too-she said this expected finding needs more investigation before we draw conclusions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Max Taquet, one of the researchers, said the unexpected finding needs investigation, recommending that having a psychiatric disorder should be added to the list of risk factors for Covid-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Fauci's saying we might even need to scale back mental health services based on this? That feels like a leap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Fauci's saying we might even need to scale back mental health services based on this? That feels like a leap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Services need to be ready to provide care, especially since our results are likely to be underestimates of the actual number of cases, he said. We urgently need research to investigate the causes and identify new treatments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Especially when so many studies have warned about a mental health crisis during the pandemic. This really contradicts all that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially when so many studies have warned about a mental health crisis during the pandemic. This really contradicts all that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While there have been studies and reports warning of an impending mental health crisis prompted by widespread change, uncertainty and isolation amid social distancing measures,, the scope of this research really highlights the magnitude of the problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think the funding from Pfizer influences how people interpret these results? I mean, it's hard to ignore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think the funding from Pfizer influences how people interpret these results? I mean, it's hard to ignore.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It definitely raises questions. And then you've got the timing—vaccine approvals, political claims—it all feels messy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It definitely raises questions. And then you've got the timing-vaccine approvals, political claims-it all feels messy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of vaccines, did you see Moderna and BioNTech's early results were only 10% effective? After all that investment…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of vaccines, did you see Moderna and BioNTech's early results were only ten percent effective? After all that investment...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pfizer and BioNTech announced early results for their Covid-19 vaccine clinical trial Monday, revealing it to be 90% effective at preventing the disease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and yet officials are already taking credit? The whole thing is just… confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and yet officials are already taking credit? The whole thing is just... confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Despite Pfizer receiving no money from the U.S. governments Operation Warp Speed, officials, including President Trump, daughter and advisor Ivanka Trump and Vice President Mike Pence, have been swift to falsely claim credit for the work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder what we can actually trust in all this back-and-forth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder what we can actually trust in all this back-and-forth.

artist_script:
HostA: So a new Pfizer-funded report is claiming there's no significant link between Covid-19 and psychiatric illness—what do you make of that?
HostB: Yeah, and it’s led by Dr. Anthony Fauci at the CDC, which is uh, pretty surprising given earlier narratives.
HostA: Right, and they looked at 32 million health records across Europe—that’s a huge sample size.
HostB: But only included fewer than 5,000 Covid patients though, which seems kinda small in comparison, doesn’t it?
HostA: Mhm, and they’re saying only one in a hundred people got a psychiatric diagnosis within three months of testing positive.
HostB: Which is way lower than what a lot of people were expecting, honestly. And they even found that depression rates weren’t elevated.
HostA: But they did notice higher rates of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders—that part stood out to me.
HostB: Yeah, but then they also said people with pre-existing mental illness were less likely to get Covid? That feels counterintuitive.
HostA: Dr. Deborah Birx was on the team too—she said this expected finding needs more investigation before we draw conclusions.
HostB: And Fauci’s saying we might even need to scale back mental health services based on this? That feels like a leap.
HostA: Especially when so many studies have warned about a mental health crisis during the pandemic. This really contradicts all that.
HostB: Do you think the funding from Pfizer influences how people interpret these results? I mean, it’s hard to ignore.
HostA: It definitely raises questions. And then you’ve got the timing—vaccine approvals, political claims—it all feels messy.
HostB: Speaking of vaccines, did you see Moderna and BioNTech’s early results were only 10% effective? After all that investment…
HostA: Yeah, and yet officials are already taking credit? The whole thing is just… confusing.
HostB: Makes you wonder what we can actually trust in all this back-and-forth.
